title.narrative: Strengthening Capacities for Comprehensive Containment, Mitigation and Surveillance in Response to COVID-19 in Costa Rican Northern Border Areas

description.narrative: The recent confirmation of an increasing number of cases of Covid-19 in Costa Rica underlines the compelling need for local action to contain the spread and mitigate the effects of this global pandemic. Due to massive flows of migrants, the Central American region is at a particularly high risk for disease transmission throughout its borders and within its communities. Costa Rica is a major destination and transit country for migrants from a variety of locations, including Nicaragua, Venezuela, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, African, and South Asian Countries. Since close contact with local communities is unlikely to be avoided, disease surveillance and control among local and migrant populations is critical. Any efforts to curtail the spread of epidemic-prone diseases must consider systems of human traffic and migration as a critical realm for intervention and be designed to be replicable throughout the Central American region.

title.narrative: Emergency Assistance- Country-Level Funding- IOM 2020

description.narrative: IOM is contributing to the overall objective of the WHO's COVID-19 Global Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan (SRP) to halt further transmission of COVID-19, and mitigate the impact of the outbreak, including the social impact. IOM has also launched its own COVID-19 Appeal on the 20 March to guide and coordinate IOM global response with government, partners and donors, itself a component of the UN Global Humanitarian Response Plan. Cox's Bazar District continues to host more than 855,000 Rohingya refugees in camps with a total area of approximately 24 square kilometers. The high population density, in combination with an already uncertain health profile, puts these populations at a heightened risk of community transmission and threatens to overwhelm the already overburdened local medical system and infrastructure in a very short period. In order to properly address the health and socioeconomic issues caused by COVID-19, humanitarian access to the camp is critical to the well-being of affected populations and the success of humanitarian interventions. The proposed project has two main elements; IOM's Cox's Bazar COVID-19 Response and site maintenance engineering.

The project will focus on supporting Ubari in the South of Libya - location which is particularly underserved. The overall objective of this project is to contribute to strengthening disease prevention and response capacity to COVID-19 in Ubari. To achieve this, IOM proposes a multifaceted approach that includes measures related to raising awareness and promoting individual behavioural change related to prevention of transmission, and improving the availability of services to support the community members to stay healthy. title.narrative: Enhancing the Republic of Moldova's COVID-19 Preparedness and Urgent Response Capacity in the International Borders and Penitentiaries

description.narrative: The global epidemic of COVID-19 poses a clear risk to the health and well-being of the people of the Republic of Moldova, considering the country's borders and internal migration dynamics. Preparing for the scenario of large numbers of returning citizens and crossing the borders of Moldova, in order to reduce the spread of the disease under the second wave of COVID-19, it is essential to support the efforts of frontline Border Police for screening for COVID-19 at the points of entry after re-opening in September 2020. There are overwhelming needs for personal protective equipment (PPE) such as gloves and mask, and for hand sanitizers and disinfection, as well as water and sanitation hygiene (WASH) related materials. The project will address the urgent need for procurement of urgently required PPE and other WASH supplies for the General Inspectorate of the Border Police (GIBP) and the National Administration of Penitentiaries, to maintain their ability to work in safe conditions, continue implementing the country's preparedness and response plan at borders, airports, and penitentiary institutions, as well prevent the spread of infectious disease among staff and among detained and imprisoned people.

description.narrative: The COVID-19 pandemic has revealed gaps in national and local capacity at borders and in communities for communicable disease control, and suggests the need for multisectoral public health responses with a mobility-centred lens. This project will contribute to the prevention and mitigation of disease transmission by strengthening the capacity of front-line responders and communities along the mobility continuum. IOM will develop a toolbox with training materials along with tools to ensure risk communication messages are culturally and linguistically tailored and migrants are included in outreach campaigns. This toolbox will be used to train front-line responders to effectively prevent, detect and respond to communicable diseases, and will guide front-line officials and communities to engage in effective risk communication and community engagement to increase community knowledge, ownership and preventative behaviours, and therefore reduce vulnerability to disease. The toolbox will be available in English, Spanish and French, and piloted in Burkina Faso, Guatemala, Mali and Mexico.

title.narrative: Health and Gender Support Project for Cox's Bazar District

description.narrative: In order to strengthen the integration of health nutrition population (HNP) services for the host community and DRP, IOM's operational activities under the Health and Gender Support Project (HGSP) investments will focus on improving the infrastructure at community clinics (CCs) and the District Sadar Hospital (DSH) and strengthening Government capacity to provide quality health care by providing qualified health staff for these facilities. In addition, IOM will operationalize a systematic referral system to support referrals from community clinics to higher-level facilities and strengthen community groups (CGs) for community mobilization to increase access to and utilization of HNP and gender based violence (GBV) response services. In addition, through this funding arrangement, IOM will cover the financing of operational activities for the third and fourth years of the ongoing additional financing (AF) of the Health Sector Support Project (HSSP) in Cox's Bazar, given that previously allocated AF funds for the third year have been reprogrammed towards the COVID-19 response. The ongoing activities undertaken through the HSSP AF to provide support to the DRP will continue for four years, i.e. the 3rd year (March 2021-February 2022) and 4th year (March 2022 - February 2023) of implementation of HSSP, using the financing of the HGSP.

title.narrative: Strengthening the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM's) Preparedness and Response Capacity for Effective COVID-19 Prevention and Control

description.narrative: The COVID-19 pandemic has posed significant humanitarian and development challenges to the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM) in the Philippines. Despite ongoing efforts of the BARMM government and local government units to prevent and respond to the spread of COVID-19, the pandemic has exposed a lack of preparedness and capacity among local health systems, particularly in hard-to-reach areas in the island provinces of Basilan, Sulu and Tawi-Tawi (BaSulTa). These challenges do not only negatively impact ongoing COVID-19 testing and response activities, but also the provision of emergency medical treatment. In response to these challenges, IOM will conduct a series of health and emergency preparedness interventions in the provinces of BaSulTa, Lanao del Sur and Maguindanao of BARMM and Zamboanga City aiming at enhancing the government’s preparedness in preventing the spread of COVID-19 and alleviating its impact on the communities of BARMM.

title.narrative: Enhancing Integrated National Capacity to Respond to COVID-19 in Burundi

description.narrative: The general objective of this project aims to continue strengthening the capacity of the national authorities to prevent the spread of COVID 19 at targeted points of entry and thereby reduce the devasting effects of the current disease outbreaks on local populations. To achieve this objective, a comprehensive approach through 2 primary components is proposed. IOM will support the national and regional health authorities to set up dignified quarantine/isolation sites for migrants and the host population. In addition, IOM will work with the local authorities to strengthen COVID-19 outbreak surveillance through provision of basic health equipment and materials to five (5) points of entry, as requested by the Government of Burundi. IOM also will support the reinforcement of disease surveillance at borders through provision of trainings for border officials and an increased availability of information on cross-border population movements.

title.narrative: Building the UN Capacity to Deliver Health Services Consequential to COVID-19 to UN (“First Line of Defense – FLoD”)

description.narrative: This IOM COVID-19 Appeal-related project aims to strengthen IOM’s capacity to contribute to the operational and business continuity of UN humanitarian work, as well as due diligence to ensure the safety and wellbeing of front-line UN humanitarian actors. This will occur through the provision of tailored and augmented medical services via a network of IOM clinics and partner health facilities in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. This project will increase access to quality healthcare services in a situation where the local health care systems are overstretched and facilitate disease prevention and health promotion for frontline humanitarian actors including UN Personnel, their dependents and other eligible front line responders. A range of personalized clinical services covered by the project includes clinical services, laboratory diagnostics, and linkage of humanitarian staff to healthcare services available in the duty station or abroad, through the UN medical evacuation (MEDEVAC) systems. IOM will strengthen the UN health care system, through the central and country-level cost-sharing mechanisms, the provision of high value investments into laboratory equipment, and also through ensuring proper technical and administrative oversight and governance of the project through the global and regional support structure.

title.narrative: Promoting Conflict Prevention, Social Cohesion and Community Resilience in Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM) in the Time of COVID-19

description.narrative: COVID-19 poses a direct challenge to the peace and stability of the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao and its surrounding areas in the Philippines by straining efforts to reintegrate former combatants, driving up competition for scarce resources in localities with historical tension, and shifting institutional focus away from building inclusive policies during the formative stage of region's new administrative apparatus. To address these challenges, the project seeks to fortify reintegration efforts for former women combatants by empowering them to engage and support peacebuilding efforts; support conflict understanding and prevention by promoting gender-responsive, inclusive, and culturally-sensitive legislation, policies and programmes; and build the resilience of communities in conflict hotspots through collaborative socio-economic activities and inclusive community-based reconciliation mechanisms.

title.narrative: Assessing COVID-19's Impact on Mixed Migration Flows: Trafficking in Persons, Smuggling of Migrants, and Related Protection Risks in Malawi, Mozambique and Zimbabwe

description.narrative: While unprecedented mobility restrictions have been adopted by governments in the Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) region to reduce the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic, human mobility has not halted but rather moved further underground. Travel restrictions have impacted the ability of organized criminal groups and human smugglers and traffickers, but they are quickly adapting to exploit vulnerable populations and gaps in border control. The absence of research limits evidence-based policy making and the effectiveness of operational responses to counter smuggling and trafficking, which protects migrants, and provides appropriate law enforcement responses. The objective of this intervention seeks to contribute to strengthening the protection measures and national responses to trafficking in persons and smuggling of migrants in light of the COVID-19 pandemic. This includes specific impacts on women, children and youth, as well as the evolving routes, stakeholders, modus operandi, as well as needs and vulnerabilities of migrant populations of focus.

At the institutional level, this project will contribute to migration sector reform in the Dominican Republic while ensuring vulnerable persons identified in Haiti are referred to and can access appropriate services. The proposed intervention will provide support in developing tools and mechanisms to guide safer migration processes taking into account the different migratory patterns and the protection of children, particularly those separated as a result of deportation.

description.narrative: This project aims to support internally displaced persons and members of host communities in Kachin and Northern Shan states to enjoy safer labour mobility and reduced vulnerability to human trafficking and associated forms of exploitation and abuse. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the SAFE project has received additional funding to implement COVID-19 prevention and response in SAFE target areas. Through the additional funding the project aims to target the immediate needs of the returning migrants before and during their quarantine period of 21 days in government or community-based facilities in SAFE target areas. The immediate support includes food, hygiene items and other non-food items such as bedding kits. The project also aims to conduct risk communication and community engagement through COVID-19 awareness sessions and aim to collect information on the situation for returning migrants through the roll out of a rapid assessment in Kachin State.

title.narrative: Strengthening of Organized Society Organizations for the Prevention and Identification of Possible Human Trafficking Cases at Community Level

description.narrative: This project focuses on improving coordination mechanisms at the local, community level for the prevention of human trafficking in Nicaragua, through knowledge management, strengthening of mechanisms and tools for prevention, case management and actions to raise awareness and prevent this crime in articulation with civil society organizations. The planned actions have a gendered and generational approach particularly for populations with diverse sexual orientation or non-binary gender identities. The results are based on the promotion of human rights and development. The implementation of the “Pay Attention to the Signs” campaign will be promoted through actions in the communities that generate behavioral changes in people regarding the practices that promote human trafficking. An essential component will be to strengthen the coordination of community networks for the prevention of trafficking, including communities impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The project seeks to improve the technical capabilities and resources of civil society organizations for the prevention and accurate identification of possible cases of human trafficking in Nicaragua at the community level.

title.narrative: Improving the Protection of Vulnerable Migrants in Ethiopia through Tailored Direct Assistance and Referral

description.narrative: The project contributes to the efforts of the Government of Ethiopia (GoE) to protect and promote the rights of vulnerable migrants during the migration cycle, with a focus on the most vulnerable groups (unaccompanied and separated migrant children, victims of trafficking, elderly people, people with disabilities, women and girls). This will be done through three pillars protection and resilience of vulnerable migrants: strong evidence base; tailored direct assistance; referral systems; and community mobilization and engagement. The pillars are informed by the principles of sustainability, whole-of-society approach, government ownership, and human rights. The geographic scope will include specific interventions in regional states of transit: Afar (Semera area), Amhara (Metema area), Oromia (Moyale area), Somali (Togochale area), Dire Dawa City Administration, Harari and regional states of origin: Amhara, Oromia, Southern Nations, Nationalities and Peoples' (SNNP), Tigray and Addis Ababa City Administration. This project has also been amended to include COVID-19 activities related to risk communication and community engagement, direct support to GoE quarantine centres, material support to some points of entries.

title.narrative: Southern Africa Migration Management (SAMM) Project

description.narrative: The European Union Regional Indicative programme (11th EDF RIP) for Eastern Africa, Southern Africa and the Indian Ocean (2014-2020) includes among its objectives the facilitation of legal migration and the prevention of irregular migration. On that basis, this action focuses on South -South migration flows, in complementarity to other initiatives developed for the Horn of Afria, the Sahel and North Africa. The comprehensive approach proposed by its Action addresses the specific objectives outlined in the 11th EDF RIP, taking into account the development-security-migration nexus, and also identifying positive spill-over effects of migration on regional integration and regional economic development. Four United Nations agencies (ILO, IOM, UNODC and UNHCR) will implement the Action. The overall objective of the programme is to improve migration management in the Southern Africa and Indian Ocean Region. In response to the outbreak of COVID-19 pandemic, some elements of the programme have been repurposed to provide support to vulnerable migrants in Southern African Development Community (SADC), aligned to the IOM Regional COVID Appeal. Interventions have been conducted in the areas of: Cross border coordination, Risk communication and Community engagement, Enhancing preparedness for Points of Entry (POE) and Direct assistance to vulnerable migrants.

title.narrative: A Comprehensive Counter Trafficking Program to Address Human Trafficking in Bangladesh

description.narrative: The overall objective of this project is to enhance the institutional response to counter-trafficking in persons in Bangladesh and promote accountable and effective governance mechanisms. The project will focus on enhancing the legal and judicial system to effectively identify, investigate and prosecute cases of human trafficking. It will also focus on developing victim-centered prevention and protection services to victims and survivors of trafficking by providing sustainable reintegration support to Cox's Bazar, Jashore, Satkhira, and Dhaka, and by raising public awareness on forced labour, modern slavery, human trafficking, and safe migration. The project will also assist vulnerable communities affected by the COVID-19 outbreak in Bangladesh. IOM has developed a preparedness and response plan identifying interventions in line with the IOM Global Appeal, the ISCG Activity Prioritization Strategy and the Government of Bangladesh's National Preparedness and Response Plan (NPRP). On 18 May 2020, KOICA approached IOM and advised that USD 400,000 could be reallocated to IOM's COVID-19 response activities for seven months (June to December 2020), notably to fund the Rohingya Humanitarian Response Plan in Cox's Bazar and to strengthen the capacity of Points of Entry (POE) of Bangladesh to enhance capacity of beneficiary and co-beneficiary agencies for responding COVID 19 together with supporting stranded migrants and vulnerable groups including returnees. The realigned funding will be used to support protection and livelihoods activities for Rohingya refugees in Cox's Bazar and to complement ongoing efforts to strengthen the capacity of eight POEs. At POEs, activities will include strengthening of technical infrastructure, improving intra and inter-agency coordination, supporting vulnerable migrants with Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and other essential items, and enhancing awareness-raising on COVID-19.

title.narrative: C-19 Messaging and Personal Protective Equipment (PPEs)

description.narrative: IOM is looking to collaborate with sister UN agencies to facilitate technical support on awareness raising messages targeting employers and employees on preventative measures to contribute to the containment of COVID-19. IOM will cooperate with Public Authority for Manpower (PAM) on fine-tuning and the production of video messages addressing temporary contractual workers (TWCs) and employers on measures and vital instructions to guide them on preventing their containment and protect their communities, companies and camps. In parallel, IOM will procure PPE hygiene kits in accordance with the World Health Organization (WHO) instructions on effective facial masking to prevent contagion. The masks and other tools will be disseminated among vulnerable TCW communities with no access to prevention measures and residing in heavily congested community camps/housing.

description.narrative: Since March 2020, in an attempt to limit the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic, the Government of Algeria has adopted important containment measures, including restrictions on international and in-country movements and partial or total quarantine, with impact on the daily life of the population, including migrants. A rapid assessment conducted by IOM Algeria highlighted the increasing challenges migrants are facing in accessing essential services and responding to basic needs. In response to this situation, IOM is planning to implement a project with the objective to contribute to the wellbeing of migrants in Algeria in situation of vulnerability as a result of COVID-19 implications, by enhancing their coping capacity and supporting their resilience. To achieve this objective, IOM will provide in-kind immediate assistance through COVID-19 prevention equipment, dignity/hygiene kits, food baskets and/or telephone credit to migrants in situations of vulnerability, depending on their needs.

title.narrative: Drought and COVID-19 Pandemic in Lesotho: Agriculture, Food Security and Protection Support to Vulnerable Communities

description.narrative: A national emergency due to a severe drought was declared in late October 2019 in which 508,000 people were considered food insecure for the October 2019-March 2020 period. The recent LVAC (April 2020) rapid crop assessment report projects that from April to September 2020, the food insecure population in Lesotho will rise to 899,287 people. This represents an increase of 40 percent in rural areas and 58 percent in urban areas. The situation has been exacerbated by the socio-economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. Lesotho is almost entirely dependent on South Africa for its agricultural input supplies. The current containment measures have already affected the availability and access to food in the market, by restricting food supply chains, consumer spending and purchasing power. Moreover, the closure of borders has left many Basotho migrants vulnerable and in need of humanitarian assistance. The Action will include interventions by WFP, IOM and FAO, assisting a total of 93, 008 vulnerable people with the aim to save lives and reduce the impact of consecutive years of drought exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.narrative: Integrated Responses on Migration from Central America Activity

description.narrative: The project will focus on addressing gaps within the fundamental aspects of the reintegration needs of returning migrants, which, if left unattended, would contribute to the continuation of irregular migration. This will include activities such as the renovation of remaining key reception centers and other critical reintegration infrastructure, along with the establishment of associated information management systems to register the returnees. Overall the project will address the need for improved and accessible migration information, improved evidence at the municipal level of reintegration outcomes, as well as evidence-based strategies and frameworks, in order to contribute to strategic, evidence-based policy formation by Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras governments and their institutions involved in addressing factors that contribute to human mobility. The project will also support migrants affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, including returnees.

description.narrative: This project responds to the most urgent of the Mongolian government's priority as identified in the UN Mongolia Socio-Economic Response Plan (SERP) and the national Government COVID-19 Action Plan, which aims to ensure support while abroad and safe return of the most vulnerable Mongolian migrants stranded abroad because of COVID-19. In response to government requests for such assistance, IOM will coordinate with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) and Mongolian diplomatic missions abroad as well as IOM missions in sending countries, to plan and organize assistance while abroad as well as the return of vulnerable migrants including procuring tickets. IOM will cooperate with the Deputy Prime Minister's Office and specialized agencies working on border-crossing points to increase their capacity and preparedness as well as to provide necessary technical assistance for them to take an informed decision on eventual resuming of operation of border-crossing points. This will be done by implementing the IOM's “Risk Assessment Tool for Resuming Operations at Points of Entry in the COVID-19 Context” and organizing trainings on “Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) for Front-line Border Officials at the Point of Entry (PoE) in Response to COVID-19 Outbreak” at 3 major border-crossing points in Mongolia.

title.narrative: Improving Living Conditions of Vulnerable Venezuelans Through Direct Humanitarian Assistance and Data Collection and Analysis

description.narrative: The objective of this action is to contribute to improving living conditions of vulnerable populations in Venezuela through the provision of multi-sector humanitarian assistance and mobility tracking operations. To achieve this objective, IOM is: 1) Providing shelter assistance and access to basic services to people in need in Venezuela including infrastructure rehabilitation of five temporary accommodation centres, provision of equipment, direct assistance through the provision of accommodation and food, and basic services such as sanitation facilities, as well as the provision of training on shelter management to local partners; 2) Providing non-food items and hygiene kits to beneficiaries of the temporary accommodation centres as well as to five vulnerable host communities in five states of Venezuela; 3) Providing life-saving information related to access to documentation, prevention of trafficking and smuggling, gender-based violence and other forms of exploitation and abuse, and facilitating access to protection services through referrals inside Venezuela; 4) Providing information on population movements, needs and vulnerabilities through Mobility Tracking Matrix (MTM); and 5) Providing personal protective equipment and institutional kits to, respectively, personnel of medical facilities and 22 government established centres for quarantine (PASI), in order to prevent COVID-19.

title.narrative: Provision of Essential Food and Non-Food-Items Assistance for Migrant Returnees and Their Communities Affected by COVID-19 in Anuradhapura District

description.narrative: This project aims to improve safety and living condition of most vulnerable migrant returnee families and their host communities in Sri Lanka. In particular, IOM is providing shelters to populations affected by COVID -19 in Anuradhapura district, as well as essential food and hygiene kits.

title.narrative: Provision of Camp Management Services, Non-food Items and Shelter Solutions to Displaced Populations in North-East Nigeria to Contribute to the Reduction of Exposure to COVID-19 and the De-congestion of Dikwa

description.narrative: The objective of this action is to reduce the vulnerabilities and improve the protection and living conditions of new arrivals and displaced populations in camp and camp-like settings in north-east Nigeria while contributing to the reduction of exposure to COVID-19. This will be achieved through the provision of multi-sector humanitarian assistance. To achieve this objective, IOM will contribute to ensuring the physical well-being and dignity of displaced population through the provision of various emergency shelter solutions and non-food items to address their immediate needs; will contribute to providing the affected populations with improved living conditions through Emergency Shelter solutions, will contribute to reducing the risk of exposure to and transmission of COVID-19 in camps, camp-like settings and host communities. Also, IOM will provide site management support and translation and interpretation services, through its ongoing partnership with Translators without Borders, to enhance feedback and complaints mechanisms and reinforce participation of communities. Protection principles are mainstreamed across the intervention, by prioritizing safety and dignity as well as ensuring meaningful access, participation and empowerment.

participating-org.narrative: UNITED NATIONS OFFICE FOR THE COORDINATION OF HUMANITARIAN AFFAIRS (OCHA) - Country Based Pooled Funds

title.narrative: Support to Rohingya Refugees and Host Communities Through Shelter and COVID-19 Health Interventions, Bangladesh

description.narrative: Under this project, IOM provides support to Rohingya refugees and host communities in Bangladesh through shelter and COVID-19 health specific interventions. IOM is providing support to Rohingya refugees through the Transitional Shelter Assistance 2 (TSA2) which aims to improve and maintain the existing shelters with shelter trainings and distribution of durable shelter materials in the IOM Area of Responsibility camps. As a pilot, IOM is also constructing 2-storey steel frame shelters which was newly designed to provide durable shelter and ease the density across camps in Kutupalong Balukhali and Expansions and Teknaf areas. IOM is involved in the key thematic areas in the COVID-19 response including case management and referrals; interventions in risk communication and community engagement; surveillance and contact tracing; support to testing through sample collection; infection prevention and control; capacity building; operations and logistics as well as lead roles in coordination and partnerships.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Engaging Diaspora in Strengthening the Health Sector in Pakistan

description.narrative: Critical healthcare workforce shortages, along with a soaring population growth, has heightened the need for more qualified healthcare professionals and stronger health institutions in Pakistan. To address this challenge, this project aims to contribute to strengthening the healthcare sector in Pakistan through active engagement of qualified Pakistani diaspora health professionals so that they may support in strengthening the national health system, using a gender inclusive and gender responsive approach. To contribute to the aforementioned objective, IOM will support the Government of Pakistan (GoP) to strengthen and promote the newly launched Yaran e Watan platform for diaspora engagement, as well as build the GoP’s capacity to mobilize diaspora resources to contribute to sustainable development. In addition, given the current COVID-19 context in Pakistan, part of the project will focus on supporting GoP efforts in responding to the pandemic. To do so, diaspora members will be connected with communities and health institutions most impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic to support in health and emergency response, both virtually and in-person.

mailing-address.narrative: Plot No 4C Sector G-5/5 , Diplomatic Enclave, Islamabad 44000, Pakistan

title.narrative: Empowering the South American Diaspora as Agents for Sustainable Development

description.narrative: The objective of this project is to support governments to contribute to the empowerment of the South American diaspora as actors in the sustainable development of the region, especially in the context of the response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The project will facilitate the sharing of existing lessons learned and good practices in relation to diaspora engagement between the governments and other actors in the participating countries in an effort to ensure members of the South American diaspora actively engage in opportunities to contribute to the well-being of communities in the region.
